comments.commentBody: Sounds great.  Now all you need is 2/3rds of congress and 3/4ths of the states agree to change the constitution..

Time to call a joint session of congress. Then lock the doors and hold new elections. Limit campaigning to 4 months before elections, no private donations and make voting mandatory, allowing voters to vote all week.
Congress seems to be one of the few places with upward mobility. Join congress and soon become wealthier than any of us know.

This is why cognitive psychology is exciting! If it can be said artwork A is objectively better (subject to the definition of "better") than B, whoever makes the claim & can provide evidence should submit to a peer reviewed scientific (not philosophical) journal. I don't agree w/ Prof. Gutting that "there is no need for such a proof [of objective superiority of one piece of music to another]", if factual superiority is his argument. It's possible, for example, levels of aesthetic response will be measured to a high degree one day in cognitive psychology or neuroscience. This is a comment on my doubt of objectivity at the level implied in the article, not that all conclusions are definitely wrong.

He has a great point about the danger of less accessible art being ignored; but the final sentence assumes too much - that lovers of popular & fine art are inherently separate, as is the art.

An argument came up in comments from Mr. Hill: "even plumbing varies in quality [let alone art]". I appreciate the passion, and as an artist, would love to completely agree; but the example illuminates my point. We know if a leaky faucet is fixed & the underlying physics are well documented. I'm not saying it's impossible to get closer to truth in this case, but right now it seems at best we can perhaps reach a consensus in certain areas rather than objectivity; ideally delivered in a tone that avoids seeming wishy-washy, while containing humbleness that comes from realizing we may be wrong.
"..read in the New York Times..." that is the newspaper that always puts race on the front of every issue.
@Howard - I take it that if you are ever attacked by someone who repeatedly slams your head against concrete that you won't fight back?

Did you ever consider that possibly ZImmerman purused other black males, because all or most the crimes in his neighborhood where perpetrators had been witnessed, were perpetrated by black males?

Pretending that black males don't commit most of the crimes of burglary and robbery in any given neighborhood, doesn't mean that they don't commit most of these crimes in any given neighborhood.

People cannot be considered in any sense "guilty" or "racist" for using common sense and considering suspicious, those who are, in view of the facts, most likely o be suspicious.

All homicides are local, Mr. Adler. Usually the killer and the victim are separated at most by yards, not miles. So being local doesn't rule out a federal prosecution.

I've read in the NY Times that Zimmerman pursued many other "suspects" in the same way he pursued Martin, and that all of these were African American. Yet the judge didn't allow race to be mentioned! This suggests that something important was missing from the trial. You can't blame the jurors, who had to decide on the basis of what was presented to them. But pretending that race doesn't exist doesn't mean that racism doesn't exist.

So, if I follow your logic William Case, if 100% of crime is committed by white Americans then suspicion of all white Americans in that community is justified under any an all circumstances, and merits following those suspicious merely for being white to prevent them from committing a crime which you have no idea whether or not they plan to commit.  Unless you agree to that, then your argument falls apart.
William Case - Following a person while carrying a gun isn't pursuing them?

@ William Gordon, Jr. – “if 100% of crime is committed by white Americans” why would anyone on the Neighborhood Watch follow a Black, Hispanic or Asian person?
“If 100% of crime is committed by White Americans” would it not make sense to follow white Americans? In your opinion William would that “following” be profiling White Americans or does it just make good sense and an expeditious use of resources and time?

"Unless you agree to that" William you have NO argument!

I've read in the NY Times that Zimmerman pursued many other "suspects" in the same way he pursued Martin, and that all of these were African American.  Yet the judge didn't allow race to be mentioned!  This suggests that something important was missing from the trial.  You can't blame the jurors, who had to decide on the basis of what was presented to them.  But pretending that race doesn't exist doesn't mean that racism doesn't exist.

A more thoughtful article would consider James Buchanan's Public Choice literature. Your article does not get to first base, as you ignore economics, the foundations of constitutional law, and collective decision-making altogether.

We cannot assume that public officials are completely benevolent. See, Federalist No. 51 (all men are not angels). The very notion of complete benevolence in public affairs is not possible because the "public good" is not found, but determined through procedure. And procedure is riddled with technical problems surrounding popular consent inherent in any democracy. Consider the filibuster debate in the United State Senate as we speak.

Economics is not an exact science, but the premise of your article does not even take into account what little we do know; that there is a balance between self-interest and benevolence in all of us. The public investment in private enterprise you champion fosters the "political grudges and fear-mongering" that you casually dismiss. We should develop institutions where ambition counters ambition, not a system where we have blind faith that somehow political grudges will not arise.

For a more thoughtful legal and economic case study of a public-private partnership, consider the public purchase of a hockey arena in Columbus, Ohio, where political pressure is present and intellectual reasoning is suspect. Available here: http://www.hastingsconlawquarterly.org/archives/V40/Ebersole_Final.pdf.

My internet wasn't working yesterday, so this joke might be a bit stale. (Not the Nick-complaint photo, that applies to Joel's puzzle). I'm referring to the appearance of NEWT Gingrich in yesterday's puzzle - I'd been waiting for that to appear all 2012 just so I could post this:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WsXtCPE7Ww

The comparison here is only within a small subgroup of musical sounds made by humans in a particular time frame. If we are to appreciate complexity, than what of the symphony of awakening accomplished by our feathered friends, the birds? Every morning hundreds of birds raise their incredible voices as the sun rises. Does sound or music as you experience it depend on human design, or only human performance?

Do readers really understand how bad is the incompetence level of the Republican leadership? McConnell and Rove and their minions bring new meaning to governing incompetence. Do you want proof? Three things are pasted below. The first is the pathetic story and picture showing the GOP Senators and Congressman with President Bush when he signed the bill which guaranteed that firearms and ammunition manufacturers could not be held responsible or liable for the distribution or manufacture of their products. The second is the Republican nosedive chart which shows the effect of the piloting by Mitch McConnell and Karl Rove and his minions since 2000.

The pathetic group shot:

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/28/us/gun-makers-shun-responsibility-for-...

And the nosedive story and chart:

http://www.people-press.org/2013/02/26/gop-seen-as-principled-but-out-of...
That worked for me, too, until the reality of my addiction sank in and I could not consume enough in one day to maintain my initial levels of calm. For me personally, this was a temporary fix.

I'm glad that you found something that helps ease your suffering.  But, lest anyone think that cannabis is the right drug for everyone, I personally find that marijuana exacerbates my anxiety, panic and feelings of depersonalization to the point that I am unable to leave my home.   Just like any FDA-recognized psycho-pharmaceutical treatment, marijuana will work like a miracle drug for some but leave others in a worse state than before its use.

Though I will likely take a daily dose of citalopram for the rest of my life, the thing that really changed my quality of life has been cannabis. Every evening after work I vaporize a small amount of marijuana, and I have never been more spiritually and mentally well.

The crippling panic attacks are ancient history thanks to high quality indica cannabis that I might spend $400/year on.
What's scarier, the fact that I'm repeating myself, or the fact that I can't see anyone's avatars?
Love the Aaron Neville clip. I had to buy a few of his albums after watching your clip.

Hi Nick,

A few people are having issues with the avatars today. It could be that a server that your computer calls when you look at Wordplay is down. I'm sure it's being fixed as we speak.

Deb "Sounding Like I Know What I'm Talking About Is 80% Of My Job" Amlen

My internet wasn't working yesterday, so this joke might be a bit stale. (Not the Nick-complaint photo, that applies to Joel's puzzle). I'm referring to the appearance of NEWT Gingrich in yesterday's puzzle - I'd been waiting for that to appear all 2012 just so I could post this:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WsXtCPE7Ww

"R's are more interested in governing, D's more interested in transforming"

Wrong. D's are interested in governing--which includes finding solutions to problems as they come up. R's are more interested in stopping any action to solve any problem facing us. They seem to think that if the country is really, really bad, voters will punish the president and the Ds and elect R's. This amounts to simple treason for venal reasons.

The cooling off nature of the Senate is over-rated. Nothing would ever pass if the Senate will only "rein in transformative efforts" because they "haven't been adequately debated". Who decides what has been adequately debated? Ted Cruz? According to the R's, global warming hasn't yet been established or "fully debated".

The R's remind me of the band on the Titanic, playing away as the ship went down. The only difference being that they must also be seen in the role of the iceberg that caused the crash in the first place.

"R's are more interested in governing..." Simply not true, especially in the Senate minority obstructing the body from exercising its constitutionally mandated duty of advice and consent.
I'm not against the filibuster, by the way. But the shortcut adopted in the 1970s has been abused enough. Return to the actual tradition of the filibuster: NO other business can be conducted during a filibuster, and the filibuster must *actually be conducted.* Historically, no filibuster EVER took place with any hope of derailing legislation favored by a simple majority. Now it is used as a cudgel to require a supermajority (not found anywhere in the Constitution short of Constitutional Amendments and conviction in a trial after impeachment) for ALL legislation. This is the R's interested in transforming, by use of obstruction.
The only thing with which I am in agreement is that Harry Reid ain't no LBJ. For a former prize fighter, he is amazingly shy about engaging in normal political combat.
R's are more interested in governing? Get real. R's don't believe in government.

This isn't the first time for this, and it won't be the last. Whenever the parties and issues are sufficiently close and polarized, and PARTICULARLY when that grease of effective governance, money, is notably absent, we get defections. Remember when the Senate lost Bill Bradley (D-NJ) in 1997? He was a highly effective moderate voice from the left, not seeking reelection mostly because he didn't wish to become part of a minority made so by Republicans. It was a shame, because he was a good senator, even if afflicted by whatever demons made him a Democrat.

But we're likely to get more defections from D's than R's this time around, because D's are by nature more impatient: R's are more interested in governing, D's more interested in transforming. In the current environment, there is precious little room for transformation since they lost the House to R's; and D's will leave. That doesn't bode well for Mr. Reid's majority post-2014.

But the federal government will be fine, despite your inaccurate perception of Senate dysfunction: the Senate's true purpose is to rein in transformative efforts that haven't been adequately debated, and at that they're performing admirably. In an electorate basically split down the middle, you're simply not going to get the kind of legitimacy that lends itself to transformation, anyway. So, Mr. Reid is wrong: the Senate is not "broken" -- it simply doesn't bow to him as he believes it should. Indeed, it shouldn't; and he ain't no LBJ.
Martin, Sigh.
Saying it twice doesn't make it any less nonsensical.

Mark:

Thanks ... I think.

The similarity could be that despite the fact that David is an honest conservative and I'm a solid Republican (very different), we both seek solutions that recocognize that Democrats and liberals need to be part of forming them. That sometimes makes us both pariahs, to people who read us on both sides.

And Mark, yet again:

Take a look at decisions of the so-called "independent" NLRB since Mr. Obama took office: from the right's perspective they've been unbalanced, injudicious and terribly damaging decisions that one-sidedly and without exception favor labor unions. They were supposed to be an honest mediator between interests, not an ideological hammer; yet they've become merely the administration's voice to Big Labor, perhaps the left's single most important source of support. That said, the resistance started small and grew, as Mr. Obama and his appointee have insisted on letting the NLRB wield power despite a quorum, a patently unlawful act contemptuous of law and of senate Republcians' right to have a voice in who gets seated on that board and the type of policy views they're likely to espouse. That unlawfulness will land him in federal court faster than anything else, if anyone can figure out the "standing" issue.

As to judges, almost all them have been confirmed, and those that haven't present serious ideological issues -- appoint less ideological judges and these slots would fall into the same uncontroversial category that got the others confirmed, most of them timely. That's how advise and consent is SUPPOSED to work. He's also been dilatory in offering up candidates, a fact admitted even by the left.

Mr. Obama clearly wants ideologically strident appointees: whenever this has happened, the other side in the Senate has exercised what power it could to hinder.

This isn't the first time for this, and it won't be the last. Whenever the parties and issues are sufficiently close and polarized, and PARTICULARLY when that grease of effective governance, money, is notably absent, we get defections. Remember when the Senate lost Bill Bradley (D-NJ) in 1997? He was a highly effective moderate voice from the left, not seeking reelection mostly because he didn't wish to become part of a minority made so by Republicans. It was a shame, because he was a good senator, even if afflicted by whatever demons made him a Democrat.

But we're likely to get more defections from D's than R's this time around, because D's are by nature more impatient: R's are more interested in governing, D's more interested in transforming. In the current environment, there is precious little room for transformation since they lost the House to R's; and D's will leave. That doesn't bode well for Mr. Reid's majority post-2014.

But the federal government will be fine, despite your inaccurate perception of Senate dysfunction: the Senate's true purpose is to rein in transformative efforts that haven't been adequately debated, and at that they're performing admirably. In an electorate basically split down the middle, you're simply not going to get the kind of legitimacy that lends itself to transformation, anyway. So, Mr. Reid is wrong: the Senate is not "broken" -- it simply doesn't bow to him as he believes it should. Indeed, it shouldn't; and he ain't no LBJ.
As a Frenchman said to me, with a wistful look, "Une Deux Chevaux? C'est une affaire de coeur."  I agree, and echo the sentiment for Deesses.

Laszlo, you said it all...No CONs here; only PROs.  Joel, this was fun..for ANY day. I can't believe I knew all the clues.  Usually there are unknown sports figures or movies I've never seen.  Today, my problem:  unlike Martin, I don't know John's avatar!

Clever way 2 side-step the old Emu trap, Laszlo!

We should expect no less.

Among your best work, Laszlo, but I was surprised at how you used one pair of words.

It seemed to me that you might remind us that much of the youtube PRODUCT you bring us is made possible only because of a baton-wielder* on hand to CONDUCT the orchestra!

-- Michael Tilsonthomas, F'rinstance

* -- a puzzle not too long ago clued it as a baton "twirler", I believe

I zipped through today's puzzle like and old PRO, but at times I felt it was a CON job. Regarding the theme, I am not sure if I was PRO or CON. I could go either way, after all I am a PROtestant CONtestant.

The PROfusion of quality entries caused little CONfusion and much enjoyment. Its clues did not CONfound me in a PROfound manner.

I don't think Mr. Fagliano is old enough to be a PROfessor or a father CONfessor, but his PROduct is excellent, and his CONduct quite becoming.

Let's all join in demanding more PROgress in CONgress during the next session, not unlike joining the PROcession to the CONcession stands between innings at a baseball game. Instead of outlawing or availing themselves of PROsti2tion, they should try harder to uphold the CONsti2tion.

On that happy note, good night all.

Polls show a lot of those guys -- most? -- like the GOP and vote for their candidates...

"And that's all I have to say about that." (Forrest Gump)

The U.S. has a long tradition of older employees working for younger men leading projects. For example, in manufacturing, senior production people often take direction from younger industrial engineers, mechanical engineers, and electronics engineers. This has also been true in all the construction trades with newly minted civil engineers taking the lead. You'll also find it true in the military where newly commissioned ensigns and lieutenants give instructions to senior NCOs.

Did you mean older workers don't want to be led by teenage leaders at fast-food restaurants? In that case, it's not the age of the crew chiefs but the $7.75 an hour minimum wage that doesn't begin to provide a living that older workers reject.

Keep in mind we still have three people looking for work for every job available.

In addition, it's hugely unwise to throw away twenty years experience in a trade that is still relevant, such as construction, and try to become employable with only six months retraining in fields such nursing or IT specialties. If the Republicans would allow a strong infrastructure repair and replacement bill to pass, most of these older workers with highly developed skills in currently depressed but relevant trades would be re-employed.

These men of whom you speak work hard to care for their families and to build our nation. The transition they're waiting on is for the GOP to grow up and adopt policies that foster our nation's development and a decent standard of living.
Considering the latest news, I have lots more respect for cows in Montana than I do for certain individuals in Florida.
Why isn't treason mentioned more often. That's what Republicans are doing - destroying our government.

The US Senate is an intentionally undemocratic body. It was created more to represent the states and their interests than those of the people. (Senators were originally appointed by state legislatures as well.) Cows in Montana have equal representation in the Senate as the millions of people in the populous states like California, New York or Pennsylvania. The filibuster is, in turn, an inherently undemocratic invention whereby one or a few may frustrate the will of the many. The current use of the filibuster, when any member can stand up and say, "Filibuster" and everything stops, is just short of insane. How did the fake filibuster become the rule? Why?

All in all, the Senate represents those who at the founding of our nation feared popular democracy and, also, who wanted to convince the states than joining a collective entity, the United States, would not mean their interests would be trampled. Fair enough. We have now reached a stage of insurrection, of constant, unyielding roadblocking for rank politics.

There is only one purpose Mitch McConnell and his band of obstructionists have in mind: to destroy the Obama presidency. Both Democrats and Republicans should be outraged. This is not the job of govt., nor those who are elected and paid to address and resolve problems. It is the task of angry, hidebound thieves who would steal our democracy and laugh as we all suffer, as long as they win in 2016. I don't want to live in such a nation.

http://terryreport.com

About 40 years ago there was painstaking quantitative work in census data by an historian (in a senior moment I forget the name) that showed very high rates of geographical mobility ca. 1860-1880.  In my own research I learned that transatlantic steamship rates were low enough by the 1870s and 1880s that coal miners migrated back and forth to the better employment opportunities.  And immigration historians know that, for some populations, migration back to Europe was fairly common.  So yes we did have high rates of geographical mobility at least among members of the working class, at least for a time.

How do you heal?

That's a question as bottomless as debating god.

How do you heal?

When I returned from Vietnam, June 1970, it was a year after a man in my infantry company had been shot throught the head in a day long battle. Two days after my return home he drove into my parents' front yard. I'd believed him dead. I'd seen him dragged back to the med-evac. But he'd survived.

He wanted to know if we'd gotten the guys who had tried to kill him. "They knew I was hit," he said, "and they kept on trying to shoot me."

I lied. I said we had. But they kept us pinned down the rest of the day and under cover of darkness, withdrew.

I dusted off 15 guys by day's end. Three days later we did it again. I dusted off 16 more. A friend of mine was shot through the chest feet from me.

The NVA withdrew and left one body behind. How odd. They never did that. They loved their's like we loved ours. He was in a bunker in front of their position. When we forced retreat they couldn't get to him, our crossing fire was too heavy, too full of murder. He had a wallet with photos of his family. Last I saw, his body was thrown down into a bunker. He was there when a c-4 charge blew it in.

I dragged all of it around when I was talking to the man from in June. Memory is like a house with unplanned additions. There are rooms you find when you wander. Scars can be doors.

You smile at well meaners. You garden life. You do good. You grow old. You don't forget what you were.

You do good.
.

Yes, everyone knows that Democrats will be in the minority again. And you know what? We all still support this change because no reasonable person thinks what the Republicans are doing, shutting down entire federal agencies through their intransigence, is acceptable. So we are happy to live under a system where neither party can do that. If the Republican party decides to use the response to the situation they created as an excuse to entirely undue the filibuster, which Democrats repeatedly have not done, that is on them.

As far as "heed the concerns of the opposition party" goes, you must have been one of those Republicans (i.e. the majority) who thought that Romney was going to win, and that all the scientific evidence saying otherwise was a liberal conspiracy from the liberal (fill in the blank) pollsters. Obama has nominated Republicans to cabinet level positions, over the strong objection of most liberals. So frankly I have no idea what you are talking about. He is trying to "stymie" the concerns of the minority by appointing qualified people he wants to the branch of government he runs?

You know it is perfectly fine to have a strong political conviction, whether liberal or conservative. But that should not blind you to the obvious. Every party does stupid and inappropriate things from time to time. In this instance, it's clearly the Republicans. Acknowledging that doesn't make you disloyal; it makes you rational.

"We just need to give them 24 hours". Though I don't personally doubt the good will of Senator Corker of Tennessee, I wonder if he or other Senators really understand that most Americans are ABSOLUTELY fed up with a government which does not work -- on any level. The rest of us go to our jobs every day and get something done, while the people elected to represent us apparently get paid for this idiotic brinksmanship while none of America's pressing problems are addressed. I would say to Sen. Corker and others, "Do you want Istanbul or Rio on your hands or do you want to do your jobs??? Because the American people are really sick of these kabuki excuses and paying you to pretend you can't compromise with other elected officials. DO YOUR JOB!

The filibuster is an important tool that makes the Senate a more deliberative body when used properly.

I am reminded of a quote by then Senator John F. Kennedy when he along with Ted Sorensen wrote Profiles in Courage:

“It is compromise that prevents each set of reformers from crushing the group at the other end of the political spectrum.”
― John F. Kennedy, Profiles in Courage

I believe the Filibuster. It needs to remain. However, the overused highly abusive tactics must end. In order to do that, it must be difficult for a Senator to invoke a filibuster. If it is a principle over tactics go for it. But in the future a Senator must speak on the floor of the Senate and not be able to filibuster by writing in and requesting it --- the mantra should be:

No Filibuster in Abstensia!!!!!

This ax cuts both ways but clearly the Senate is broken. I recommend caution and compromise with mandatory presence on the floor to speak though to the end of such filibuster.
Don't forget "DC Madam" David Vitter from Louisiana-- the state that's half under water and half under indictment!
The Democrats keep nominating moderate Republicans.

The filibuster needs to go, period.  This move is long overdue.  There's already a tyranny of the minority - witness that Montana with a population of about 1 million people has two senators, while California, with 38 million people, gets . . . two senators.  Enough already!  Get rid of the filiibuster in ALL cases!
